Description: Dynegy Inc., agreed to pay $3 million to settle allegations of accounting improprieties and misleading statements arising from Dynegy's improper accounting for and misleading disclosures relating to a $300 million financing transaction, known as Project Alpha, involving special-purpose entities (SPEs), and Dynegy's overstatement of its energy-trading activity resulting from round-trip or wash trades resulting in neither profit nor loss to either transacting party.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2002-140.htm

Company: Dynegy Marketing & Trade (Dynegy) and West Coast Power LLC
Info Source: http://www.cftc.gov/opa/enf02/opa4728-02.htm

Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, Dynegy Midwest Generation agreed to spend $500 million on new pollution control equipment, pay a civil penalty of $9 million, and spend $15 million on environmental projects.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/March/05_enrd_100.htm

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 2211: Electric Power Generation, Transmission and Distribution

Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: In November 2003, TXUE initiated a marketing campaign directed at approximately 67,000 former PTB customers in the Oncor area. The Campaign consisted of letters mailed to former customers inviting them to return to TXUE and offering them a $25 movie gift certificate if they switched back to TXUE. At least 540 former customers who responded to the letter and switched back to TXUE were given the promised movie gift certificate. The LED believes that offering the $25 movie giR certificate in the Campaign was an offer of a rate other than the PTB in violation of P.U.C. SUBST. R. 25.41(h). Further, the LED contends that the provision of the gift certificate to Enrolled Customers constituted charging these customers a rate different from the PTB in violation of PURA 0 39.202(e).
Info Source: https://interchange.puc.texas.gov/Documents/29661_1_437609.PDF
